facts.gratitude_fact: A regular gratitude protocal can provide resilience to trauma in two ways. First, it can help to reframe the event so it is not as difficult, and it can innoculate or prevent future suffering through the resilience it can help build. *Andrew Huberman, neurobiology and ophthalmology at Stanford School of Medicine.

Gratitude practices that help promote positive feelings of contentment are a result of the release of the neur0transmitter serotonin. Narrative story-telling, where a person shares how another person helped htem through a hard time, can provide a sense of wellbeing, as proven by studeis done inside of MRIs imaging the brain.

The fear and defence mechanisms in the brain can become less overreactive, buffering you against the harsh effects of trauma by bolstering your resilience to difficult circumstances through a regular gratitude practice.
Simply writing a list of what you are grateful for has no proven efficacy at boosting your brain health or causing feelings of wellbeing.

Grateful people experience fewer aches and pains and they report feeling healthier than other people, according to a 2012 study published in Personality and Individual Differences. Not surprisingly, grateful people are also more likely to take care of their health.  They exercise more often and are more likely to attend regular check-ups with their doctors, which is likely to contribute to further longevity.

Grateful people are more likely to behave in a prosocial manner, even when others behave less kind, according to a 2012 study by the University of Kentucky. Study participants who ranked higher on gratitude scales were less likely to retaliate against others, even when given negative feedback. They experienced more sensitivity and empathy toward other people and a decreased desire to seek revenge.

stories.story: Jacie was the director of a preschool I was a new teacher at. She showed me by example how to do things, never shaming me. Her presence, skills, and generosity of time to expose me to those lessons taught me more than I ever learned in school. She taught me so much about leadership, generosity, fun, music, and being yourself without a single lecture.
stories.thank_you_note: Jacie, thank you for showing me by example and never judging me

comments.comment:
“Many people are alive but don’t touch the miracle of being alive.” 
– Thích Nhất Hạnh, author of The Miracle of Mindfulness: An Introduction to the Practice of Meditation
“The way to develop the best that is in a person is by appreciation and encouragement.” — Charles Schwab

“So the point is to acknowledge what’s difficult in life, but don’t let it hijack your attention. Don’t let it suck you out. And instead, as much as you can, focus on what there is to be thankful for. Which among other benefits will make you stronger.” — Rick Hanson
“None is more impoverished than the one who has no gratitude. Gratitude is a currency that we can mint for ourselves, and spend without fear of bankruptcy.” — Fred De Witt Van Amburgh

“Gratitude turns what we have into enough, and more. It turns denial into acceptance, chaos into order, confusion into clarity… it makes sense of our past, brings peace for today, and creates a vision for tomorrow.” — Melody Beattie
“If it’s out of your hands, it deserves freedom from your mind too.” – Ivan Nuru
